title: Rory McIlroy will continue to focus on America tour because courses are 'too easy' on home circuit
text:
Rory McIlroy has told the European Tour that he will continue to concentrate on America because the courses are “too easy” on his home circuit.

McIlroy posted a final-round of 69 at the Dunhill Links to finish on 15-under, but found himself in a tie for 26th. After coming in a tie for ninth on 11-under the previous week at the PGA Championship at Wentworth, McIlroy, who has barely played on the European Tour in 2019, made his frustrations clear.

“I'm honestly sick of coming back over to the European Tour and shooting 15-under and finishing somewhere around 30th - I don't think the courses are set up hard enough,” McIlroy, the world No 2, said. “There are no penalties for bad shots. It's tough when you come back when it's like that. I don't feel like good golf is regarded as well as it could be.

“It happened at the Scottish Open [in July]. I shot 13-under and finished 30th. It’s not a good test. I think if the European Tour wants to put forth a really good product, the courses and setups need to be tougher.”

His comments will make depressing reading at Wentworth HQ. McIlroy eventually consented to rejoin the Tour in May, but is clearly displeased and plainly more adamant than ever to focus on the Stateside circuit. He won the $15m FedEx Cup first prize last month and feels that the criticism he has faced has been unjust and pointed out the appearance fees he is turning down on the European Tour.
description: Rory McIlroy has told the European Tour that he will continue to concentrate on America because the courses are “too easy” on his home circuit.
